title: 114_hr5607
content: The Act is titled the "Enhancing Treasury's Anti-Terror Tools Act" and examines the Department of the Treasury's counter-terror financing role in embassies. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of the Treasury must report to specific committees on the status of Treasury attaches at US embassies, including permanent and temporary assignments, and how anti-terror finance issues are handled at other embassies. The Secretary of the Treasury must report on the reporting structure for addressing anti-terror finance issues, the role of Treasury attaches in advancing anti-terrorism financing interests, trends identified in the previous year, recommendations for improving coordination with foreign financial ministries, and the Department of the Treasury's interests in anti-terror finance issues. Some embassies or regions may lack representation in addressing money laundering and illicit finance issues. SEC. 3. CLARIFYING REQUIREMENTS FOR RECORDKEEPING. Section 5326 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to clarify requirements for recordkeeping related to funds as described by the Secretary. The amendment clarifies recordkeeping requirements for funds as described by the Secretary, replacing "coin and currency" with "funds" in the regulation. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on potentially turning the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence into a standalone bureau. A report on the findings must be issued within 270 days to relevant committees. Additionally, efforts to enhance monitoring of funds transfers for anti-terror finance will be improved. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study to assess the efficacy of a pilot program for providing technical assistance to institutions serving money services businesses in Somalia. The study will also evaluate the impact of allowing money services businesses to share their State examinations with financial institutions. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue a report within 270 days of the enactment of the Act to provide findings and determinations on the study assessing the effectiveness of a pilot program for technical assistance to institutions serving money services businesses in Somalia. The report will also evaluate the impact of allowing money services businesses to share their State examinations with financial institutions. The term "money services business" is defined under section 1010.100 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. The Congress urges the Secretary of the Treasury to collaborate with finance ministries globally to establish intelligence entities like the Office of Intelligence and Analysis to enhance anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing efforts.
